title: 108_hr4437
content: The Act titled "Medicare Prescription Drug Low-Income Assistance Act of 2004" ensures assistance for low-income beneficiaries in Medicare savings programs under the Medicare prescription drug discount card and transitional assistance program. The Medicare Prescription Drug Low-Income Assistance Act of 2004 includes automatic enrollment of certain low-income beneficiaries in Medicare savings programs, with notices sent out within 45 days of eligibility for an endorsed discount card program. The Medicare Prescription Drug Low-Income Assistance Act of 2004 allows eligible individuals to enroll in an endorsed discount card program and receive transitional assistance. If not enrolled within 30 days, individuals will be automatically enrolled unless they opt out. Individuals enrolled in an endorsed discount card program can switch to another program within 60 days of automatic enrollment. Those enrolled in 2004 can change their enrollment for 2005. In 2005, individuals benefiting from automatic enrollment in the endorsed discount card program are not obligated to use it when purchasing prescription drugs. This includes those receiving supplemental security income benefits under title XVI or eligible for medical assistance under title XIX. The Secretary will automatically enroll individuals eligible for endorsed discount card programs if they have not enrolled or provided notice within 30 days of eligibility. The Secretary automatically enrolls eligible individuals in endorsed discount card programs unless they opt-out within 30 days. Individuals can change their card program within a 60-day grace period. Individuals enrolled in endorsed discount card programs have a 60-day window to switch to a different program. Low-income beneficiaries in Medicare savings programs have a special transitional assistance rule. Low-income Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in endorsed discount card programs have a 60-day window to switch programs. Special transitional assistance rules apply to those receiving supplemental security income benefits or eligible for medical assistance under specific clauses. The Secretary may waive disqualification for individuals with prescription drug coverage. The amendments made by this section waive self-certification and verification requirements for low-income beneficiaries in Medicare savings programs. These changes take effect as if included in the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003. The Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003 (Public Law 108-173; 117 Stat. 2071) was enacted. SEC. 3. Assurance of assistance for low-income beneficiaries in Medicare savings programs under qualified prescription drug coverage. Automatic Enrollment amendment to the Social Security Act for full-benefit dual eligible individuals who have not enrolled in a prescription drug plan or an MA-PD plan. The Social Security Act amendment allows for automatic enrollment of full-benefit dual eligible individuals who have not enrolled in a prescription drug plan or an MA-PD plan. The Secretary will apply notice, opt-out, and grace period provisions in change in enrollment. The Secretary will apply notice and change in enrollment provisions for prescription drug plans and MA-PD plans similar to those for endorsed discount card programs. Additionally, provisions for premium and cost-sharing subsidies for Medicaid beneficiaries and low-income beneficiaries in Medicare savings programs will be provided. The Secretary will treat certain part D eligible individuals as subsidy eligible individuals, including full-benefit dual eligible individuals, recipients of supplemental security income benefits, and those eligible for medical assistance under title XIX. The amendments made by this section will take effect as if included in the enactment of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003.
